channel.title: CNBC International TV
channel.description:
CNBC is the recognized world leader in business news and provides real-time financial market coverage and business information to approximately 385 million homes worldwide.
With international headquarters in London, Singapore, and Abu Dhabi, CNBC International covers news and features from Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia Pacific.
Subscribe to CNBC International TV for the very best of CNBC's international programming, including top business news moments and award-winning original documentaries and feature series.
For real-time news updates from around the world, visit CNBC's website: http://www.cnbc.com
Subscribe to our other YouTube channel here: https://www.youtube.com/user/CNBCInternational/
Like our Facebook page www.facebook.com/cnbcinternational
Follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/CNBCi

item.description: Nancy McKinstry, CEO at Wolters Kluwer, discusses the company's full-year results, her outlook for growth in 2023, and the resilience of the U.S. consumer.
item.title: Wolters Kluwer CEO: Share buyback of 1 billion euros planned for 2023
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Benjamin Ho of the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies discusses China's position on the Russia-Ukraine war and says it is playing the long game, though there are many other ways it can assist Russia.
item.title: China is 'certainly in no hurry' to provide lethal weapons to Russia, says assistant professor
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: There will be a strong decoupling from China in tech and security, according to the CEO of Berlin Global Advisor Jan Kallmorgen, who doesn't advise investing in the country.
item.title: Analyst sees move away from investment in Chinese tech, security
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Sri Mulyani Indrawati, Indonesia's finance minister, says there are some downside risks from exports.
item.title: We expect our economy to grow up to 5.3% this year, says Indonesia minister
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Sweden has fulfilled conditions it agreed to at the NATO Summit in Madrid last summer, so it is time for the Turkish Parliament to begin the ratification process, Tobias Billström, Sweden's minister of foreign affairs, told CNBC.
item.title: Sweden NATO membership is happening, Swedish foreign minister says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Suhaimi Ilias of the Maybank Investment Banking Group says Malaysia's budget this year is likely to retain the people-friendly tone of the budget that was tabled in October 2022.
item.title: Malaysia's 2023 budget: Expect another year of fuel subsidies, Maybank says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: John Woods of the investment bank says India will continue to underperform for the first couple of quarters of 2023.
item.title: Foreign investors are making a 'pronounced rotation' from India to China, says Credit Suisse
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Swedish Defense Minister Pål Jonson told CNBC's Silvia Amaro that giving Ukraine fighter jets is difficult, because Sweden needs them to maintain [its] territorial integrity.
item.title: Giving Ukraine fighter jets is 'difficult' because we need them, says Sweden's defense minister
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Lotfi Karoui of the investment bank says whether the U.S. Federal Reserve cuts interest rates in the first or second quarter of 2024 is up for debate.
item.title: U.S. Fed 'definitely' won't cut interest rates this year, Goldman Sachs says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Ted Galen Carpenter of the Cato Institute says the problem is that the goals keep escalating.
item.title: Biden's Kyiv visit suggests the administration is doubling down on its support for Ukraine: Analyst
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Solvay's chief financial officer Karim Hajjar says what we can do is expect to navigate that.
item.title: Solvay CFO: We expect to maintain profitability, but we can't defy gravity
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Latvian President Egils Levits speaks to CNBC's Steve Sedgwick in Warsaw ahead of the one-year anniversary of Russia mounting a large-scale invasion of Ukraine.
item.title: Latvia president: Ukraine conflict cannot end until Russia moves back to recognized borders
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire speaks to CNBC's Tanvir Gill at the G-20 meeting in Bengaluru, India.
item.title: French Finance Minister: Not time to water down G-20 communique on Ukraine war
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Robert Koenigsberger of Gramercy Funds Management discusses investing in Russia, Ukraine, and the spillover effects of the war.
item.title: Russia is 'uninvestable' from a legal and fundamental perspective, says investment firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Mathias Cormann, secretary-general of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, discusses the global outlook for 2023 and India's Group of 20 presidency.
item.title: Outlook for oil prices is 'slightly brighter than what it was,' says OECD secretary-general
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Jan Jenisch, CEO of Holcim, discusses the company's earnings and the outlook for inflation in 2023.
item.title: There's no recession at Holcim, CEO says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Cliff Kupchan of Eurasia Group says the Chinese are probably aiming to burnish their own image … in the Global South.
item.title: China is likely to offer a peace plan for Russia and Ukraine, consultancy says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Peter Albert, CEO of 29Metals, says that's driven by decarbonization and net-zero goals around the world.
item.title: The outlook for copper is 'tremendous,' says copper producer
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Trinh Nguyen of Natixis says imports, on the other hand, will really drag growth.
item.title: It's China's export engine that will be 'really driving' growth, economist says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Jean-Jacques Morin, deputy CEO and CFO of the French hospitality company, discusses its momentous milestone and the outlook for 2023.
item.title: Accor: 2022 was the first time we went above 2019 levels
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Saint-Gobain, chief financial officer at Sreedhar N., discusses the firm's full-year earnings.
item.title: Saint-Gobain CFO: We're confident about bringing 'very strong' results in 2023
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Andy Brough, head of the European small- and mid-cap team at Schroders, shares some underlying causes for optimism on the U.K. economy and financial markets.
item.title: UK economy in 'a lot better shape' than GDP figures suggest, fund manager says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Manishi Raychaudhuri of the French bank discusses the two big themes it's playing in China.
item.title: BNP Paribas says it's more positive on mainland China than on Hong Kong this year
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Jim Chalmers, treasurer of Australia, says both countries have an interest in having a peaceful, prosperous, stable, secure region.
item.title: We're putting in a lot of effort to stabilize our relationship with China, says Australia treasurer
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Sachin Mittal of the Singapore bank says the nature of Grab's business is a low-margin one.
item.title: DBS Bank says it wasn't positive on Singapore-based Grab, but it's 'more comfortable' now
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Stefan Meister, head of the Center for Order and Governance in Eastern Europe, Russia, and Central Asia at the German Council on Foreign Relations, discusses Germany's attitude toward the war in Ukraine.
item.title: Germany supports Ukraine but is concerned about escalating tensions with Russia
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Mike Henry, CEO of the mining company, says demand is likely to pick up toward the end of this calendar year.
item.title: We expect to see stronger steel and iron ore demand from China, says BHP
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Keith Barr, CEO at IHG, discusses the company's results, the removal of Chinese Covid restrictions, and employment trends in the hospitality and leisure industry.
item.title: IHG CEO: Demand returning to pre-pandemic levels
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: John Freeman of CFRA Research discusses the firm's position on Baidu and the Chinese tech company's plan to implement the chatbot in March.
item.title: Baidu's Ernie Bot chatbot has 'tremendous potential,' says investment research firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Microsoft President Brad Smith speaks to CNBC's Arjun Kharpal following a meeting with European Union officials on Tuesday, as his company tries to convince regulators that its planned $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard will be good for competition.
item.title: Microsoft President Brad Smith says it's a 'good day for gamers' after Nintendo, Nvidia deals
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Paolo Gentiloni, European Commissioner for Economy, says Brussels is discussing the 10th package of sanctions against Russia.
item.title: Further sanctions on Russia are being discussed, says European Commissioner for Economy
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen spoke to CNBC's Tanvir Gill at a news conference ahead of a G-20 financial leaders meeting in Bengaluru, India.
item.title: U.S. will resume economic talks with China 'at an appropriate time,' Yellen says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Ruslan Kogan, CEO of Kogan.com, says the company has transitioned to a capital-light business model over the past few years.
item.title: Online retailer says majority of its sales are driven by software and subscriptions
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Du Hyeogn Cha of The Asan Institute for Policy Studies discusses two ways to manage those tensions.
item.title: North Korea-South Korea ties: Tension shouldn't be avoided but managed, think tank says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Larry Diamond of Zip says buy now, pay later is the credit card of tomorrow for the customer of tomorrow.
item.title: We're very focused on the fundamentals of the business, says Australian 'buy now, pay later' firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Tim Baker of the bank says inflation isn't going away — it looks worse than where we were a few months ago, for the U.S., for Europe, for other places.
item.title: Central banks have to do more to get inflation 'out of the system,' says Deutsche Bank
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: How the war in Ukraine ends will largely depend on the decisions made by Ukraine's allies with regards to Kyiv's ongoing weaponry needs such as long-range missiles and jets, Lithuania's President Gitanas Nauseda told CNBC.
item.title: Ukraine's weaponry needs must be met, Lithuanian president says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Chua Soon Hock of Asia Genesis Asset Management says he's still bullish on dollar-yen and the trend is quite clear.
item.title: Dollar-yen could reach 140 level within the next two months: Asset management firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Sushant Gupta of Wood Mackenzie says China's reopening is a big factor.
item.title: We expect oil prices to be largely influenced by demand in emerging economies: Wood Mackenzie
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Rolf Bulk of New Street Research says the moment that they hit that, the stock should also become a lot more attractive for investors.
item.title: Singapore-based Grab is on a clear path to profitability, analyst says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: CNBC's Hadley Gamble reports live from the International Defence Exhibition in Abu Dhabi.
item.title: Russia's presence at the UAE defense expo is hardly hidden
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Atsushi Katsuki of the food and drinks business says rising wages would lead to an increase in personal consumption, which is good for our company's business performance.
item.title: We would see rising wages in Japan as favorable, Asahi Group CEO
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Faisal Al Bannai, chairman of the board of directors of UAE's leading defense group Edge, says it's not focused on the lower end of the market.
item.title: There's been a 'significant' rise in international demand for our products: UAE defense group
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Norway and its neighbors have to be prepared for rising nuclear risks, following Russia's decision to suspend its nuclear-arms treaty with the U.S., Norwegian Foreign Minister Anniken Huitfeldt tells CNBC.
item.title: 'We have to be prepared,' Norway's foreign minister says of nuclear risks
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: William Ma of Grow Investment Group says consumption will be a big theme for the mainland China and Hong Kong markets this year.
item.title: Not many global investors are buying into China's reopening story yet, says investment firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Michael Yoshikami of Destination Wealth Management predicts a shallow recession because the Fed has increased interest rates [sufficiently] to significantly slow down the economy.
item.title: We're probably going to see a 'shallow recession,' says wealth management firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: William Courtney, adjunct senior fellow at Rand Corporation and former U.S. ambassador to Georgia and Kazakhstan, says Russian forces have been depleted and it's not clear that they will be able to mount a new effort that will seriously challenge the Ukrainians.
item.title: Russia may not be positioned to carry out a large-scale offensive, says former U.S. diplomat
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description:
Exercising command and control isn't necessarily the only way to get the best out of a team, according to Paul Marriott, President of SAP, Asia Pacific, Japan.
Instead, fostering an environment of trust and empowerment will pave the way for high performance, he told CNBC's My Biggest Lessons.
Trust is all about setting the standard. The standard you walk past is the standard you set, Marriott, who is also a youth rugby coach, said.
And by being empowered to set that standard higher, better outcomes will follow.
In a game of sport like rugby, the outcome is winning the game. There are steps and rules to get there, as long as they're followed, then drive to the bigger outcome.
This is just one of Paul Marriott's biggest lessons. Watch the video above for more.
---

item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: The Federal Reserve is going to be very data-dependent this year, says WisdomTree Equity and Commodity Strategist Aneeka Gupta, and remain slightly hawkish through the first half of the year before easing off.
item.title: Fed hawkishness will be a tale of two halves this year, strategist says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Jiong Shao of the bank discusses the Chinese tech giant's earnings beat and says it is generating cold, hard and very good cash.
item.title: Alibaba's not getting enough credit for having such a profitable business model, Barclays says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Vanessa Chan of Fidelity International says the United States could face a shallow recession in 12 to 18 months' time.
item.title: Relatively high chance U.S. will fall into a cyclical recession, says investment management firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Daniel Roeska, managing director of automotive research at Sanford C. Bernstein, weighs in on euro zone car registration numbers, outlining which car stocks he believes will perform best in 2023.
item.title: Seeing really positive trends in European auto sector despite weak macro setting: Bernstein

item.description: Damian Thong of Macquarie Capital Securities says that for virtual reality to become really mainstream, it has to be accessible to a mass audience, not just a gamer audience.

item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Valeo CEO Christophe Périllat discusses the firm's earnings as the French car parts maker received record orders last year, and forecasts growth in the year ahead.

item.description: Carl Bildt, who served as Swedish prime minister from 1991 to 1994 and is now policy advisor at Covington & Burling LLP, says the war has been a massive strategic failure from the Kremlin's point of view.

item.description: Heimo Scheuch, CEO at Wienerberger, discusses the company's full-year results, the impact of rising interest rates on the real estate industry, and how the company has diversified to overcome these challenges.

item.description: Nadia Calvino, Spain's economy minister, says the outlook for the country is relatively positive.

item.description: John Todaro of Needham says institutions are in part sidelined from the space, waiting for that regulatory clarity, at least here in the United States.

item.description: Mary Ng, Canada's minister of international trade, export promotion, small business and economic development, says there will be areas that Canada will absolutely challenge China on, but diversification, for me as a trade minister, is the job.
item.title: We're clear about our relationship with China in the Indo-Pacific strategy, says Canadian minister

item.description: Microsoft has got Nintendo and NVIDIA on its side for it proposed acquisition of Activision Blizzard. But it is still struggling to convince regulators, CNBC's Arjun Kharpal reports.

item.description: The Yong family, which is behind one of Singapore's largest construction firms, Woh Hup, speaks to CNBC's Christine Tan about cultivating a culture of giving in the company and in the fifth generation.

item.description: Noel Quinn, CEO of HSBC, discusses the outlook for 2023 and its fourth-quarter earnings for 2022.

item.description: Christoph Jurecka, CFO of German reinsurer Munich Re, breaks down the company's fourth-quarter results and how it achieved a 74% year-on-year profit increase.

item.description: Bill Perkins of Skylar Capital Management says crude looks especially bullish in the six- to 12-month time frame, but things are looking more bearish for natural gas.

item.description: Vishal Harnal of the venture capital firm says, however, that capital allocation from institutional investors who have had decades of experience investing in venture capital really isn't shrinking.

item.description: CNBC's Tania Bryer talks to Filippo Grandi about how the UNHCR is supporting refugees in the region one year after the beginning of the full-scale invasion which created one of the largest displacement emergencies in the world.

item.description: Andrew Lim of the real estate investment management company says Singapore's policy responses are meant to tame an engine that is showing signs of overheating.
